briefing.opening: Good day. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 5, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Response Challenges
sections.content: Climate change is already occurring, raising the need to strengthen food security [1], and its impacts are evident across ecosystems, including a decline in alpine frog populations [51] and accelerated gorgonian reproductive cycles [63]. In particular, climate change poses a direct threat to human health by increasing the risk of cognitive decline and neurological crises through heatwaves [50, 59], and it is also making the future of the Winter Olympics and Paralympics uncertain [54, 58]. Domestically, the carbon neutrality plans of 31 basic local governments in the Daegu-Gyeongbuk region have been evaluated as 'failing' [11, 12], highlighting deficiencies in policy responses. Furthermore, safety warning lights have been activated for aging renewable energy facilities [23], requiring caution during the energy transition process. Internationally, research has been published indicating that economic models underestimate climate change issues [56], and the UK's announcement of plans to cut climate finance for poorer nations by one-fifth [66] has raised skepticism about climate crisis responses. Additionally, claims have emerged that climate modeling is diverging from climate science [60].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Carbon Neutrality Implementation Efforts and Institutional Improvements
sections.content: Domestically, as legislation for greenhouse gas reduction pathways progresses [3] and the need for public discourse on climate is raised, various efforts to achieve carbon neutrality are continuing. The 'Carbon Neutrality Point System,' which provides cash benefits for reducing mileage, has been expanded, with 2.7 billion won in incentives paid over the past five years [7, 15]. Mokpo City is promoting eco-friendly vehicle dissemination projects [8], and Yangju City is implementing a 'one person, one tree planting' initiative [19], moving closer to their carbon neutrality goals. Seongbuk-gu is accelerating progress towards its 2050 carbon neutrality target through resident-led practical activities [9, 10]. Cheonan City has launched the 'Cheonan City Carbon Neutrality Center' [13], and Daejeon Daedeok-gu has renamed its facility to 'Daedeok Carbon Neutrality Life Practice Center' [18], strengthening its carbon neutrality implementation hubs. Notably, Haenam County has achieved the distinction of being officially recognized as the 'No. 1 Carbon Neutrality County,' overcoming rural limitations [14]. Asan City Council aims to enhance carbon neutrality implementation through the enactment of a 'Climate Response Fund' ordinance and amendments to ordinances supporting energy management and the dissemination of new and renewable energy [22, 34, 37, 40].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Infrastructure Expansion
sections.content: Efforts by the government and local authorities to accelerate the transition to renewable energy are active. The Korea Energy Agency held a comprehensive briefing session this year to support renewable energy dissemination [24]. Incheon Jung-gu is accelerating its efforts to create a leading new and renewable energy city by promoting convergence support projects, collaborating with five companies on new and renewable energy projects, and providing 80% of installation costs [25, 31, 33, 38]. Cooperation between central and local governments is being emphasized to achieve a renewable energy transition that is tangible to the public [26]. Various local governments, including Geoje City Council, are working on institutional improvements by holding public hearings for amendments to urban planning ordinances to expand new and renewable energy [28, 32, 35]. Furthermore, Gwangju Bank and LG Ensol are collaborating to vitalize renewable energy VPP (Virtual Power Plant) projects [30]. Samsung C&T is successfully monetizing its Australian solar and ESS project rights, accelerating its overseas energy platform strategy [39, 41].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Awareness of Climate Change and Multi-layered Responses
sections.content: The international community is exploring diverse perceptions and response strategies regarding climate change. As California's chocolate manufacturers demonstrate efforts to adapt to climate change [45], responses across various industrial sectors are becoming crucial. Meanwhile, debates on climate change information and perception are active, with the 'climate change Christmas carol' work titled 'Vigil' sparking controversy [42], and claims emerging that some climate change charts are incorrect [53]. In a reality where many children feel despair about climate change [44], the Wildlife Society is seeking to advance research and on-the-ground solutions regarding the impacts of climate change on wildlife [48]. The Carolina Conservation Program plans to emphasize the role of food in climate change [52]. In Rhode Island, legislation is being discussed that could make polluters pay for the costs of climate change impacts [46]. Michigan has filed a lawsuit, accusing major fossil fuel companies of being a 'cartel' that fuels the climate crisis and high energy costs [67]. In the summer of 2026, a new overseas study program will be held in Zambia, adopting a 'glocal' perspective on climate change [55]. Prince Albert II is encouraging international climate action by presenting the Olympic Climate Action Award in Milan [64].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlights the severity of the climate crisis, alongside the coexistence of various domestic and international response efforts. We hope that sustained attention and action will enable us to build a better future. This concludes today's climate briefing.
